tossups.question: Residents of this state often bake a many-layered cake called bebinca for Christmas. Those residents of this state also prepare an alcoholic beverage from cashews called feni. A close relative of psychedelic trance music is named for this state because it was developed by people in its beach town of Anjuna. The body of St. Francis Xavier is stored in this state's Basilica of Bom Jesus. Daman and Diu [Dee-oo] were formerly part of this state when it was a union territory. The curry dish (*) vindaloo originated in this state. Konkani is an official language in this state, alongside Marathi [muh-RAH-tee]. Panaji is the capital of this state, whose largest city is named for Vasco da Gama. Maharashtra and Karnataka surround this state. For 10 points, name this Indian state which was a former Portuguese colony.
tossups.answer: Goa

tossups.question: If the roots of the characteristic polynomial of an SHO ["S-H-O"] are related by application of this function, [read slowly] c is less than root 4 m k, and the SHO is underdamped. Applying this function to a unitary matrix gives its inverse, while applying it to a Hermitian matrix gives its transpose. This function of the root of a real-coefficient polynomial always yields another root. Multiplying a (*) complex number by this function of itself gives the square of its magnitude. Applying this function is equivalent to flipping the sign of the argument. Geometrically, this operation is a reflection about the real axis, and it's often denoted by a horizontal overbar. For 10 points, name this operation that flips the sign of a complex number's imaginary part.
tossups.answer: complex conjugation [accept word forms like complex conjugate]

tossups.question: In the second measure of a work by a composer from this country, clarinets and brass synthesizers enter with a rapid three-note ostinato; that work is marked "delirando." Decrescendoing low strings open the "The Anfortas Wound" second movement of a work by a composer from this country titled for a Schoenberg textbook. The latter of two "fanfares for orchestra," written for the Great Woods Festival by a composer from this country, includes polyrhythms in the three (*) woodblocks and is titled Short Ride in a Fast Machine. That composer from this country memorialized 9/11 survivors in On The Transmigration of Souls. For 10 points, name this country home to the post-minimalist composer of operas like Nixon in China, John Adams.
tossups.answer: United States of America [accept America or the USA]

tossups.question: A New York newspaper summarized this battle as one side "assaulting its jailer, but is still in jail." One side in this battle made three 180 degree turns, sending its battlecruisers on a "death ride." Another side in this battle deployed to port from 6 rows of 4, crossing the enemy T. The HMS Revenge and HMS Agincourt sighted the Seydlitz during this battle, but did not attack. Although he was initially able to sink the Indefatigable, Reinhard (*) Scheer withdrew to Wilhelmshaven after losing to John Jellicoe in this battle, thus not allowing the British to destroy their fleet. This battle is known as the "clash of the Dreadnoughts." For 10 points, name this battle fought in the North Sea off the coast of Denmark, the largest naval battle of World War I.
tossups.answer: Battle of Jutland [or Battle of Skagerrak]

tossups.question: A professor in a novel by this author hears telephones ring while out on a run and is told to save Marjorie Stubbs from a bomb. The narrator of another novel by this author distinguishes between "thin" and "hidden" examples of the title entities, which are named after women. The protagonist of a novel by this author meets an expert in Cimmerian languages named (*) Professor Uzzi-Tuzii while trying to get past the first chapter of books. Marco Polo discusses the title entities of a novel by this author with Kublai Khan. A novel by this author sees the protagonist fall in love with Ludmilla and is written in second-person. For 10 points, name this Italian author of Invisible Cities and If on a winter's night a traveler.
tossups.answer: Italo Calvino

tossups.question: Saul Kirpke used the "quus" [kwuhss] function to demonstrate a rule-following paradox after reading one of this man's works. This philosopher criticized G.E. Moore's statement "here is a hand" to start his essay On Certainty. In one work, this philosopher introduced the idea that "what we cannot speak of, we must pass over in silence"; that work also introduced the "picture theory of language." This philosopher demonstrated the incoherency of (*) "private languages" by having people define the contents of a box containing a beetle in Philosophical Investigations. For 10 points, name this Austrian philosopher and author of Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.
tossups.answer: Ludwig Wittgenstein

tossups.question: One of these objects is hidden on Mexico Street by the narrator after he realizes that the "best place to hide a leaf is in a forest." A footnote to a story describes a location containing these objects as "pointless" and was said by Letizia Alvarex de Toledo. The narrator of a story receives one of these objects from a Scottish salesman who got it from the "outskirts of Bikaner." Greedy individuals search for prophetic examples of these objects called (*) "Vindications" in another short story. Purifiers attempts to search for the "Crimson Hexagon" in a story about these objects. For 10 points, name these objects which are found in a Jorge Luis Borges story about the library of Babel.
tossups.answer: books [accept "The Book of Sand"]

tossups.question: This was the highest position held by a person who lost support in a presidential campaign after being supported by the KKK at the 1924 Democratic convention. The nomination of Roger Taney [TAWny] to hold this position, which was also held by William McAdoo, was the first to be rejected by the Senate. As a reward for eventually supporting Abraham Lincoln at the 1860 Convention, Salmon (*) Chase was given this position. The first holder of this position, which was later held by Albert Gallatin, proposed a tax on alcohol which led to the Whiskey Rebellion, and also proposed assuming the debts of states after the Revolutionary War. Janet Yellen currently holds, for 10 points, what cabinet position that looks over the US Mint and the Internal Revenues Service?
tossups.answer: Secretary of the Treasury

tossups.question: For a system of charges, the multipole expansion is found by using the law of cosines and writing this quantity in terms of Legendre polynomials. The Laplacian of this quantity equals negative volumetric charge density over the permittivity of free space, according to Poisson's equation. Thevenin's [TAY-vuh-nanz] theorem allows any linear circuit to be simplified into a resistor and source of this quantity. This scalar quantity is constant in a (*) conductor. The difference in this quantity is often found by taking the negative line integral of an electric field between two points. This quantity can be stepped up and down using a transformer. For 10 points, name this quantity that, according to Ohm's law, equals current times resistance.
tossups.answer: voltage [or electric potential or scalar potential; prompt on V; do not accept or prompt on "potential energy" or "vector potential"]
tossups.answer_formatted: voltage [or electric potential or scalar potential; prompt on V; do not accept or prompt on "potential energy" or "vector potential"]

tossups.question: One of these works shows a close up of a human ear under rippling water. Another of these works drew confusion because it consists solely of an unadorned photograph of a cow in a field. One of these works depicts two businessmen shaking hands outside the Warner Brothers studio, with one of the two men on fire, while in another of these works an inflatable pig hovers above Battersea power station. One of these works consists of an array of white (*) bricks with grey mortar in a depiction of the title construct. The most famous of these artworks shows a triangular prism on a black background dispersing a beam of white light into a rainbow. For 10 points, name these artworks that appear on the front of "The Wall" and "The Dark Side of the Moon".
tossups.answer: Pink Floyd album covers [or Pink Floyd cover art, prompt on album covers or albums by asking "for what band?"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Pink Floyd album covers [or Pink Floyd cover art, prompt on album covers or albums by asking "for what band?]
acceptable: Pink Floyd cover art, prompt on album covers

tossups.question: In this work, Hussein believes that he is a pen, and so slits his own throat trying to sharpen himself. Another character in this work strands his mother on the roof so he can crash a wedding, and later makes a fortune by alternating sending idols and missionaries to China. That title character of this play encounters the Boyg while fleeing from imps and nixies, and pleads with the devil to save him from being melted down by the (*) Button-Moulder. This play begins with the title character telling his mother Ase an elaborate yarn about a reindeer hunt, and ends with Solveig [SOUL-vay] singing to him. An encounter with the Dovre King of the Trolls in this play was the inspiration for "In the Hall of the Mountain King," part of a musical work based on it. For 10 points, name this Ibsen verse play, the inspiration for a suite by Edvard Grieg.
tossups.answer: Peer Gynt

tossups.question: This country's DOI-CODI [doy koh jee] secret police tortured Vladimir Herzog to death. After a series of arrests by Newton Ishii in this country, the conglomerate Odebrecht [oh-duh-bresh] was renamed to Novonor. After a leader of this country shot himself at the Catete [caw-tay-chee] Palace, Plínio Salgado returned from exile to reform its Integralist Party. "Fifty years of progress in five" was promised by (*) Juscelino Kubitschek [zhoo-say-lee-no koo-beach-check], who commissioned Oscar Niemeyer to design this country's capital. Sergio Moro led this country's Operation Car Wash, which led to the impeachment of its first female president. This country was led by Getúlio Vargas and Dilma Rousseff. For 10 points, Jair Bolsonaro leads what Portuguese-speaking South American country?
tossups.answer: Federative Republic of Brazil [or Brasil]

tossups.question: One of this author's poems describes a man whose "cheek was like a rose / In the snow" until he was cut down by "the pruning-knife of Time." Another poem by this author tells of a song heard "through the deep caves of thought." In one poem, this author laments that "The meteor of the ocean air / Shall sweep the clouds no more!", and proposes giving the title object to (*) "the god of storms / The lightning and the gale!" In addition to a poem about a "ship of pearl" which "sails the unshadowed main," this author wrote a poem that begins "Ay, tear her tattered ensign down!" and helped prevent the USS Constitution from being decommissioned. For 10 points, name this fireside poet from Boston who wrote "The Chambered Nautilus" and "Old Ironsides."
tossups.answer: Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr. [the first line refers to "The Last Leaf"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr. [the first line refers to "The Last Leaf"]

tossups.question: One building by this architect is a cylindrical building with a brick exterior and a skylight, the only window, directly above the altar. This architect designed a structure for Yale's campus that is known as "the whale" for its doubly curved form. A building designed by this architect of the Ingalls Rink features a thin-shell roof supported by four Y-shaped piers, and another in the shape of a one-eighth sphere supported by glass curtain walls on (*) MIT's campus. This architect designed a stainless steel arch in the shape of a catenary curve that is located on the Mississippi River in St. Louis, in addition to the TWA Flight Center and the Kresge Auditorium. For 10 points, name this Finnish-American architect who designed the Gateway Arch.
tossups.answer: Eero Saarinen [do not accept or prompt on "Eliel Saarinen"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Eero Saarinen [do not accept or prompt on "Eliel Saarinen"]

tossups.question: Neutron capture therapy treats tumors by first using an isotope of this element to absorb neutrons. Alternating this element and nitrogen in a six-membered ring forms "inorganic benzene." An acid of this element is used to perform an anti-Markovnikov addition of an alcohol to an alkene. A palladium complex catalyzes the cross-coupling between acids of this element and organohalides in the (*) Suzuki reaction. The wurtzite form of this element's nitride is harder than diamond. This element's trifluoride is a Lewis acid which is planar because it has only 3 bonding domains, since this element violates the octet rule. For 10 points, name this first metalloid with atomic number 5.
tossups.answer: boron [or B]

tossups.question: A city of this name was defeated by the Han general Li Guangli in the War of the Heavenly Horses; that city was known by the epithet "Eschate," or "furthest." A city of this name was located in modern-day Kandahar, and contained a copy of the Edicts of Ashoka. That city of this name in ancient Arachosia was ceded to Chandragupta Maurya along with 500 elephants by (*) Seleucus I Nicator [suh-LYOO-kus one nigh-KAY-ter]. The Eastern-most city of this name was founded after the death of a certain animal at the battle of the Hydaspes River. The most prominent city with this name contained a huge lighthouse constructed by Ptolemy II. For 10 points, give this name of cities in Asia Minor, the Middle East, and North Africa that were named for their founder, who rode the horse Bucephalus and conquered the Persian Empire in the 4th-century BCE.
tossups.answer: Alexandria [accept Alexandria Eschate; accept Alexandria Arachosia; accept Alexandria Bucephalous]

tossups.question: One recurring structure in this organelle resembles parking garage ramps and is named for Mark Terasaki. The SERCA pump regulates calcium ion concentration in this organelle, as does calsequestrin. The signal recognition particle targets proteins to this organelle's translocon. This organelle is the site of N-linked glycosylation. Vesicles leaving this organelle are tagged with (*) COPII ["C O P 2"]. One type of this organelle is found wrapped around myofibrils in muscle cells. Like the Golgi apparatus, this organelle is composed of a network of flattened discs called cisternae. This membranous organelle is continuous with the nuclear envelope. For 10 points, name this organelle, classified based on the presence of ribosomes as either "rough" or "smooth."
tossups.answer: endoplasmic reticulum [or ER; accept rough or smooth ER, accept sarcoplasmic reticulum or SR]
tossups.answer_formatted: endoplasmic reticulum [or ER; accept rough or smooth ER, or sarcoplasmic reticulum or SR]

tossups.question: This religion's principle of eternal progression is summarized "as man is, God once was; as God is, man may become." Members of this faith are asked "Are you a full-tithe payer?" and "Do you understand and obey the Word of Wisdom?" in temple recommend interviews. This religion's Plan of Salvation describes the Telestial, Terrestrial and Celestial Kingdoms of Glory. This religion's "standard works" include the (*) Doctrine and Covenants and the Pearl of Great Price. This religion is symbolized by the Angel Moroni, who members believe revealed the locations of seer stones and golden plates to its founder. For 10 points, name this Christian denomination founded by Joseph Smith and headquartered in Salt Lake City, Utah.
tossups.answer: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints [or LDS; or Mormonism]
tossups.answer_formatted: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints [or LDS; or Mormonism]
acceptable: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints
Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints

tossups.question: One character with this last name describes crying by a bag of dog biscuits after being confronted by the narrator of one book. Another character with this last name, who was likely inspired by Ginevra King, asks for her infant daughter to be "a beautiful little fool." That character with this last name falls in love with an AEF officer stationed in Camp Taylor near Louisville. A man with this last name misleads a (*) car mechanic into murdering a character in a swimming pool. The home of a couple with this last name has a "green light" that the title character of one book reaches out to. While driving a yellow car, a woman with this last name accidentally runs over Myrtle Wilson. For 10 points, name this last name shared by Tom and Daisy in The Great Gatsby.
tossups.answer: Buchanan [accept Tom Buchanan; accept Daisy Buchanan]

tossups.question: The Politics, Culture, and Class of this event were explored in a study by Lynn Hunt. One book concerning this event claimed that "the most wonderful things are brought about in many instances, by means the most absurd and ridiculous." Thousands of prisoners were murdered in this event's September Massacres, as recounted in a three-volume history of it by Thomas Carlyle. Edmund (*) Burke wrote a series of Reflections criticizing this event which argues from expenditures outlined by Finance Minister Jacques Necker. This event's "Radical" phase often begins with the storming of the Tuileries [tweel-ree] Palace in 1792. For 10 points, name this event which overthrew Louis XVI and began its country's First Republic.
tossups.answer: French Revolution

bonuses.leadin: The narrator of this poem describes a time when "it was all / Shining, it was Adam and maiden, / The sky gathered again / And the sun grew round that very day." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem, whose narrator recalls being "young and easy under the apple boughs" and "green and carefree, famous among the barns" before noting that "time held [him] green and dying."
This Welsh poet included "Fern Hill" in his collection Deaths and Entrances. He also wrote "Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night."

Deaths and Entrances also includes a "Refusal to Mourn" a child who dies during one of these events. Another poem about one of these events, by Anne Bradstreet, ends by noting that "My hope and treasure lies above."
answers: a fire [accept equivalents like a house-fire or burning]

bonuses.leadin: Adherents of this religion are known as creyentes [kray-YANE-tayse], or "believers," and often sacrifice domesticated birds in a ritual called matanza. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this syncretic religion found predominantly in Cuba. Deities in this religion are called orishas.
This orisha is the patron of thunder and lightning and is usually depicted wielding a double axe. His three wives are the river goddesses Oba, Oya, and Oshun.
Santeria developed from the combination of Catholicism and the religion of the Yoruba people, who originate from this African country also home to the Igbo.
answers: Santeria (accept Regla de Ocha or La Regla Lucumi or Order of Lucumi)
metadata: accept Regla de Ocha or La Regla Lucumi or Order of Lucumi

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about thought experiments that purport to refute the second law of thermodynamics. For 10 points each:
parts: This thought experiment posits a creature who is able to open and close the door between two compartments in order to sort particles based on their speed, thus doing work.

A "ratchet" theorized by this Polish physicist uses Brownian motion to violate the second law. With a German, this physicist names an equation that sets the diffusion coefficient equal to drift velocity times Boltzmann's constant times temperature over force.

A setup named for this scientist that supposedly violates the second law can be resolved by noting that the entropy of mixing for identical particles is zero. This scientist's namesake free energy equals H minus T S.
answers: Marian Smoluchowski [prompt on Feynman-Smoluchowski ratchet or Einstein-Smoluchowski equation] [the German is Albert Einstein]
Josiah Willard Gibbs [accept Gibbs free energy]
answers_formatted: Marian Smoluchowski [the German is Albert Einstein] [prompt on Feynman-Smoluchowski ratchet or Einstein-Smoluchowski equation]
acceptable: Marian Smoluchowski [the German is Albert Einstein]
Marian Smoluchowski [the German is Albert Einstein]

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the Federalist papers. For 10 points each:
parts: : The Federalist papers were written by James Madison, John Jay, and this person, who claimed the judiciary had "no influence over either the sword or the purse...and neither force nor will" in Federalist 78. This man was later killed in a duel with Aaron Burr.
A major argument of the Federalist Papers is that the constitutional structure would be effective against these groups, because a larger republic would make it harder for them to form.
The federalist papers were written under the pseudonym of this man, who overthrew the Roman monarchy along with Lucius Junius Brutus.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about the activist and journalist Roman Protasevich:
parts: Name this action. This action was done by a foreign government, using a bomb threat, for the purposes of arresting Protasevich. A description is acceptable.
Roman Protasevich's plane was forced to land in this country's capital, Minsk, under the orders of this country's dictator Alexander Lukashenko.

Roman Protasevich used a channel on this platform to publish his news platform Nexta [nekh-tah]. This platform, which was founded by Pavel Durov, is popular among protest movements because of its encryption.
answers: forcing a plane to land [accept air piracy or kidnapping from a plane or anything indicating that the plane was made to touch down in the next part by the government; prompt on landing a plane or anything about kidnapping or piracy that doesn't mention an airplane or anything about a plane landing that doesn't seem forced; don't accept the plane was shot down or anything mentioning weaponry (other than a bomb threat)]
answers_formatted: forcing a plane to land [accept air piracy or kidnapping from a plane or anything indicating that the plane was made to touch down in the next part by the government; prompt on landing a plane or anything about kidnapping or piracy that doesn't mention an airplane or anything about a plane landing that doesn't seem forced; don't accept the plane was shot down or anything mentioning weaponry (other than a bomb threat)]
acceptable: anything indicating that the plane was made to touch down in the next part by the government
promptable: piracy that doesn't mention an airplane
anything about a plane landing that doesn't seem forced

bonuses.leadin: In the prologue to a play titled for a character from this collection, the Manager claims that he has "lowered between the audience and the stage [a]... magnifying glass" during his description of a barnyard. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this collection, written in Middle English by Geoffrey Chaucer. In this collection, the Nun's Priest tells the tale of how the rooster Chanticleer is tricked by a fox's flattery.

This French playwright wrote Chantecler. In another play by this author, Christian de Neuvillette's repeated reference to Cyrano de Bergerac's absurdly large nose leads Cyrano to lose his temper in front of his cousin Roxane.

Another of Rostand's plays is titled for The Last Night of this figure. In a play-within-a-play, Jack Tanner dreams that he is this figure "In Hell" and converses with the Devil, who resembles the brigand Mendoza.
answers: Don Juan [accept The Last Night of Don Juan or "Don Juan in Hell"]
answers_formatted: Don Juan [accept The Last Night of Don Juan or Don Juan in Hell]
acceptable: The Last Night of Don Juan

bonuses.leadin: Examples of these diseases include Graves' disease and systemic lupus erythematosus. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these diseases, caused when the body mistakes itself as a foreign pathogen and thus attacks itself.

This autoimmune disease can be treated with DMARDs like leflunomide, an inhibitor of dihydroorotate dehydroxylase. Fibroblast-like synoviocytes contribute to chronic joint inflammation due to this disease.

To prevent autoimmune responses, mTECs in this organ display cell components in a process called central tolerance. This organ may be abnormally large or contain a tumor in patients with myasthenia gravis. Along with the bone marrow, it is the site of VJ recombination.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some things about the poetry of John Ashbery. For 10 points each:
parts: Ashbery's Self-Portrait in a Convex Mirror references this Italian Mannerist's painting of the same name. This artist's depiction of Mary in another painting was inspired by the medieval hymn "Your neck is like a column."

This is the name of a group of gender-fluid children who do battle with the Glandolinians in a Henry Darger manuscript that inspired Ashbery's Girls on the Run. In another work, a character with this first name writes the biography "My Cue" about her writing partner Clare Quilty.

An Ashbery poem beginning "A people chained to aurora / I alone disarming you" is titled Civilization and its Discontents after a book by this psychologist. This psychologist developed the notion of an Oedipus complex.
answers: Parmigianino [or Francesco Mazzola] [the second work is Madonna with the Long Neck]
Vivian [accept the Vivian Girls or the Vivians, accept Vivian Darkbloom] [the latter work is Lolita]
answers_formatted: Parmigianino [the second work is Madonna with the Long Neck] [or Francesco Mazzola]
Vivian [the latter work is Lolita] [accept the Vivian Girls or the Vivians, or Vivian Darkbloom]
acceptable: Parmigianino [the second work is Madonna with the Long Neck]
Parmigianino [the second work is Madonna with the Long Neck]

bonuses.leadin: In this opera, a brindisi drinking song is sung in the aria "Libiamo, ne'lieti calici." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this opera about the courtesan Violetta Valery, who is loved by Alfredo. This opera is based on The Lady of the Camellias by Alexander Dumas.
After Alfredo's party in La Traviata, Violetta sings "È strano! ... Ah, fors' è lui" followed by this contrasting aria in which she expresses that her "thoughts must fly" repeatedly.
La Traviata is an opera by this composer who also wrote Aida.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Norman conquest of England, for 10 points each:
parts: The Norman conquest was led by this duke, who claimed that Edward had promised the throne to him first, before the deathbed naming of Harold Godwinson as heir. This duke won the Battle of Hastings.
William conducted this "Great Survey" of England in 1086, assessing the land and peasants for tax collection.

William abolished this political institution of Anglo-Saxon England, which consisted of roughly yearly meetings to issue law codes and give advice. It had the power to depose and choose kings, and was replaced with a "king's court," or curia regis.
answers: William the Conqueror [or William I; or William the Bastard; prompt on William]
answers_formatted: William the Conqueror [or William I; or William the Bastard; prompt on William]

bonuses.leadin: A theorem partially named for this mathematician can be proved by showing that the symmetric group of order n, for n greater than 4, is not solvable. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Norwegian mathematician. With Paolo Ruffini, this mathematician names a theorem that implies the existence of quintic polynomials whose roots are not expressible by radicals.

Abel also lends his name to groups in which every pair of elements have this property with respect to the group operation. For addition, this property states that [read slowly] a plus b equals b plus a.

In analysis, Abel's theorem is often used to prove that the sum of this series is the natural logarithm of 2. The sum of this series can also be found by performing a Taylor expansion on the function ln of the quantity 1 plus x.
answers: alternating harmonic series [do not accept or prompt on "harmonic series"]
answers_formatted: alternating harmonic series [do not accept or prompt on "harmonic series"]

bonuses.leadin: One common tree in this state is also called "swamp cabbage" and can be found on the coast at resorts such as Hilton Head Island. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this state on the Eastern seaboard that is nicknamed the Palmetto State. It has a capital at Columbia.
Palmetto trees can also be found on this resort city's coast. This city's beaches are near attractions such as SkyWheel and Ripley's aquarium and are between Wilmington and Charleston.
Inland South Carolina also includes this national park home to large tracts of old-growth forest, including Bald Cypress trees whose namesake "knees" are roots that poke out of the ground.

bonuses.leadin: This quantity's namesake law says that it will decrease as price increases. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity that measures the willingness for a consumer to buy a certain good. It is contrasted with supply.
These goods violate the law of demand, since increasing their price also increases their demand. These goods are often "high-class" goods such as Supreme or Louis Vuitton products.
This quantity equals the change in quantity demanded divided by the change in price. This quantity is only positive for Giffen or Veblen goods.
answers: price elasticity of demand [or demand elasticity; accept PED]

bonuses.leadin: This event was engineered by René Barrientos to make its subject look like he was shot in battle. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this event. This event's target told Mario Terán, "Shoot, coward! You are only going to kill a man!", after telling a teacher that he was fighting for an end to the inequities that had brought her a dilapidated schoolhouse.
Guevara was executed after leading guerrillas in this country against a junta possibly advised by Klaus Barbie. This country had earlier lost its coastline to Chile after the War of the Pacific.

After learning of Guevara's execution, this leader proclaimed three days of public mourning. This leader had earlier worked with Guevara to overthrow Fulgencio Batista and establish a Communist Cuban state.
answers: execution of Ernesto "Che" Guevara [accept execution of Che Guevara; accept synonyms for execution like killing or assassination]
Fidel Alejandro Castro Ruz [prompt on Castro]
answers_formatted: execution of Ernesto "Che" Guevara [accept execution of Che Guevara; accept synonyms for execution like killing or assassination]

bonuses.leadin: In one song, this rapper states "Baby, I'm a gangster I can't help it" after being told "Boy you so selfish." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this rapper who stated "Legends Never Die, you the reason I stopped popping perks" in reference to Juice Wrld in his song "Toxic." That song appears on this rapper's 2021 album "Hall of Fame."
In April 2020, Polo G released this Billboard #1 song that states "I've been making like 2,000 a minute" and "my pants Amiri, yes I'm winnin' clearly", in addition to featuring a ukulele.
Polo G is originally from this city. Juice Wrld was also from this city's South Side where they rapped about this Illinois city's gangs.
answers: Polo G (accept Taurus Bartlett do not accept or prompt on Ralph Lauren)
metadata: accept Taurus Bartlett do not accept or prompt on Ralph Lauren

bonuses.leadin: Everybody loves geophysics, but perhaps nobody more than 19th century British mathematician A. E. H. Love. For 10 points each:
parts: Love wrote a Treatise on the Mathematical Theory of this property. A process named for this property occurs below the yield point.
Love's work on elasticity inspired him to develop a set of parameters that describe the earth's deformation under these forces. On Earth, these forces result in a periodic rise and fall in sea level.
Love also names a type of transverse surface wave formed by interference of these seismic waves that arrive after P waves and cannot pass through the outer core.
answers: elasticity [accept word forms like "being elastic"; accept elastic deformation; do not accept or prompt on "plasticity"]
S waves [or secondary waves or shear waves]
answers_formatted: elasticity [accept word forms like "being elastic; accept elastic deformation; do not accept or prompt on "plasticity"]

bonuses.leadin: This character pays David DeMarco a hundred dollars to pretend that he doesn't know who this character is. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character, who shoots Carla Jean after she loses a coin flip. This character also murders the hitman Carson Wells.
Chigurh is a killer in this Cormac McCarthy novel, which is not part of his Border Trilogy. This novel begins with Llewellyn Moss taking a bag with millions of dollars in cash from a pickup truck.
No Country for Old Men takes place in this U.S. state and Mexico. In one scene, Moss tells his wife Carla Jean that he will meet her in this state's city of El Paso.

bonuses.leadin: After this emperor stepped down, he resided in a palace in Split and became a vegetable grower. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Roman Emperor who formed the Tetrarchy during the 3rd century BCE, thus splitting up the Roman Empire.

Diocletian appointed this person his co-emperor initially, and then made him the co-senior emperor in the Tetrarchy. This man alternated between supporting and attacking his son Maxentius and his son-in-law Constantine.
Diocletian frequently persecuted these people, who had also been blamed by Nero for the Great Fire of Rome. Constantine was the first Roman emperor to support this religion.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Bohemian composer and musician Johann Stamitz. For 10 points each:
parts: Stamitz played this highest-pitched string instrument in a traditional string quartet.

Stamitz is considered the founder of a classical school named for this city. A figure named for this city pairs a quickly rising arpeggio with a crescendo, and opens the final movement of Mozart's Great G Minor symphony.
Stamitz wrote one of the first concertos for this instrument, in B-flat major. Mozart wrote an A-major concerto for an early virtuoso of this instrument, Anton Stadler.
answers: Mannheim [accept Mannheim school or Mannheim rocket]

bonuses.leadin: A story set in this location was adapted from the Konjaku Monogatari, a Heian-period collection of over 1000 short folktales from Japanese, Chinese, and Indian culture. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this location. That story titled for this location presents seven contradictory testimonies of the events surrounding the murder of Kanazawa no Takehiko in this location, including the confession of the bandit Tajomaru.
This Japanese author wrote of Takehiro's murder in "In a Grove." He also wrote "Rashomon."

Akutagawa drew from the Uji Shui Monogatari for his short story "The Nose," about a member of this profession named Zenchi Naigu. A member of this profession is the second to testify in "In A Grove" and contradicts the Bounty Hunter on the number of arrows in Kanazawa's quiver.
answers: the bamboo grove [accept "In A Grove" or "Yabu no naka"]
a Buddhist priest [accept synonyms like monk]
answers_formatted: the bamboo grove [accept In A Grove or Yabu no naka]
